On 3 July 2018, poultry farmers in Cochabamba protested by giving away their live chickens because of the increase of the cost of soy flour that would make more expensive the breeding of chicken and also to protest the creation of more breeding grounds of chickens.
On 2 July 2018, citizens of Santa Cruz, started a protest against the local authorities to demand the fulfillment of an environmental audit that ordered the shutdown of the Normandia dump.

On 29 June 2018, parents from Don Bosco school, together with parents from Gaston Vilar and Jose Mariano Serrano schools, took to the streets in Sucre city (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca) to demand the dismissal of the school primary education headmaster, who allegedly sold school places. [size=no report]

On 28 June 2018, around 400 students, teachers and administrative staff from the Public University of El Alto finished their march, started on 25 June, from Patacamaya town towards La Paz city, in La Paz Department, to demand for a better budget for the university. As part of the protest, 2 teachers crucified themselves. [size=400]

On 27 June 2018, around 400 students, teachers and administrative staff from the Public University of El Alto continued their march, started on 25 June, from Patacamaya town towards La Paz city, in La Paz Department, to demand for a better budget for the university. At the Calamarca Ventilla area, private security forces from the Educational Unit ''23 de Marzo'' tried to disperse them, with alleged orders by the Ministry of Education. [size=400]

On 27 June 2018, students from the Public University of El Alto took to the streets in La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz), staging protests in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Finance, where they wrote a letter with their own blood, and in front of the Ministry of Education, where some of them crucified themselves. Protesters demanded a better budget for the university. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2018, around 400 students, teachers and administrative staff from the Public University of El Alto continued their march, started on 25 June, from Patacamaya town towards La Paz city, in La Paz Department, to demand for a better budget for the university. [size=400]

On 25 June 2018, around 400 students, teachers and administrative staff from the Public University of El Alto marched from Patacamaya town towards La Paz city, in La Paz Department, to demand for a better budget for the university. [size=400]

On 25 June 2018, cancer health professionals and patients from Hospital de Clinicas took to the streets in La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz), blocking streets in the Miraflores area and conducting a fasting in front of the hospital, to demand medical attention, since the services have been paralysed and only those who can afford to pay for private services can get treatment. [size=no report]
On 19 June 2018, citizens outraged of an event of police brutality that killed a citizen in San Matias days before, burned down the headquarters of rural patrol nearby the city.

On 19 June 2018, a protest broke out by provincial municipalities of Santa Cruz demanding for the royalties from hydrocarbons tax that the governor owes to several municipalities. They have blocked streets in various sectors of Santa Cruz and have protested for two days

On 18 June 2018, a protest broke out by provincial municipalities of Santa Cruz demanding for the royalties from hydrocarbons tax that the governor owes to several municipalities. They have blocked streets to protest in various sectors of Santa Cruz and this is the first day of protest.

On 18 June 2018, in San Matias (Santa Cruz), a young man was shot dead by police officers after not obeying an order to stop the car. According to family members and locals, the man did not stop because the car breaks were broken. Police authorities claimed he had drugs in his possession, which was not confirmed. 1 fatality

On 18 June 2018, transportation workers affiliated with the Free Transportation Association (ATL) staged a protest surrounding La Paz City Hall, in La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz), to protest against the creation of new transportation routes proposed by the First of May Federation. [size=no report]

On 14 June 2018, Students and police forces engaged in La Paz into violent clashes involving molotov bombs, firecrackers and stones thrown to police forces, to which the police forces used tear gas and water jets to control the fights. 5 police members were injured and one student detained. Students were demonstrating about the budget assigned by the government and to modify a taxation law.

On 13 June 2018, Police forces engaged with students that were demonstrating about the budget assigned by the government and to modify a taxation law. Rioters started to throw firecrackers at the police forces, that triggered the Police to try to disperse the demonstrations by throwing tear gas against the students. After that, rioters started to throw rocks and marbles against the police forces, to which police forces used chemical agents to control the agressions. 2 people were injured including a police man, and 11 students were arrested.

On 12 June 2018, in La Paz, La Paz, supporters of Luis Castillo, elected on 3 May as president of the Federation for Neighbourhood Councils (FEJUVE) tried to take over the headquarters of FEJUVE in La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz), where the previous president, Jesus Vera, was found. Rioters claimed that it was time for Castillo to assume the presidency, and forcibly entered the building, breaking windows and vandalizing the facilities. The police forces intervened and arrested 26 supporters of Luis Castillo. [size=at least 26]

On 11 June 2018, workers from the construction company Jose Cartellone blocked the road Diagonal Jaime Mendoza in the Cuquisaca Department to demand the payment of their salaries and to protest against the uncertainty regarding the continuity of their posts. [size=no report]

On 11 June 2018, parents from Don Bosco school blocked the streets nearby the school in Sucre city (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca) and marched towards the Departmental and District Education Directorates to demand the dismissal of the school primary education headmaster, who allegedly sold school places. [size=no report]

On 8 June 2018, in Chuquisaca department [coded to Sucre], workers from the construction company Jose Cartellone blocked the road Diagonal Jaime Mendoza in the Cuquisaca Department to demand the payment of their salaries and to protest against the uncertainty regarding the continuity of their posts. [size=no report]

On 7 June 2018, in Chuquisaca department [coded to Sucre], workers from the construction company Jose Cartellone blocked the road Diagonal Jaime Mendoza in the Cuquisaca Department to demand the payment of their salaries and to protest against the uncertainty regarding the continuity of their work. [size=no report]

On 7 June 2018, students took to the streets in La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz) to demand better budget, the modification of Law 195 and the resignation of half a dozen authorities, including 2 ministers. After the march, a small group staged a demonstration on the corner between Ayacucho and Potosi streets and threw firecrackers at the police officers guarding the access to Murillo square. Rioters forcibly trespassed the fence guarding the new Government Palace, under construction, and threw painting against the facade of the building. [size=no report]

On 6 June 2018, retired teachers affiliated with the Departmental Federation for Retired Teachers staged a protest at the 25th May square, Sucre city (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca), to demand an increase of their pensions. [size=no report]

On 6 June 2018, public transport workers protested against the reorder of transport plans in Santa Cruz by blocking main streets. The main problem erupted when the mayor prohibited public transport use a specific avenue, that is being redesigned to have only private transport and bicycle lanes.

On 5 June 2018, students from the Public University of El Alto staged a vigil protest in front of the headquarters of the Federation of Neighbourhood Councils (FEJUVE) in opposition to the government. [size=no report]

On 4 June 2018, students, local inhabitants and members of social organizations took to the streets in El Alto city (El Alto, Murillo, La Paz), blocking roads in 16 points within the city to demand the government to solve the university conflict which on 24 May took the life of Jonathan Quispe, student from the Public University of El Alto, after he was shot by a police officer. [size=no report]
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 4 June 2018, affiliates to MAS-IPSP demonstrating in defence of Government Minister Carlos Romero clashed with a group of citizens supporting the 21 February 2016 referendum who were demonstrating against Carlos Romero and the government. The clash happened at 24 de Septiembre square in Santa Cruz de la Sierra city (Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Andres Ibanez, Santa Cruz). [size=no report]

On 1 June 2018, students from the Public University of El Alto (UPEA) blocked the road between La Paz and El Alto cities, in La Paz Department, to protest against the authorities, who allegedly covered-up of the death of Jonathan Quispe Vila, UPEA student. [size=no report]

In the week between 28 May and 3 June 2018, workers from the Cartellone construction company took over the camps from the construction company in ''Muyupampa'' Villa Vaca Guzman municipality (Vaca Guzman, Luis Calvo, Chuquisaca) in protest to demand the payment of 3 months worth of salary. This seems to be an ongoing strike/protest, but no further information. [size=no report]
On 28 May 2018, students and authorities of public universities protested in La Paz against the government because of the death of a student that was hit by a marble shot by police forces.
On 28 May 2018, students and authorities of public universities protested in Cochabamba against the government because of the death of a student that was hit by a marble shot by police forces.
On 28 May 2018, students and authorities of public universities protested in Santa Cruz against the government because of the death of a student that was hit by a marble shot by police forces.

On 24 May 2018, students from the Public University of El Alto took to the streets in El Alto city (El Alto, Murillo, La Paz), blocking roads in multiple points within the city, to demand a better budget for the university. During the demonstration, students clashed with the police forces. As a result, a student was killed by a marble shot by members of the police forces. [size=no report]
On 22 May 2018, a student was killed during a protest in El Alto by a marble shot by police forces during a demonstration about university budget cuts.

On 10 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi for the tenth day of protest in Chuquisaca, and eleventh day in total of strikes counting the first day in Santa Cruz. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. There is distrust of the civilians of Chuquisaca with the government because they believe the central government is biased with Santa Cruz and the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 10 May 2018, transport workers in Cochabamba blocked streets demanding that the authorities listen to their demands. However, the protest was lifted after the minister of Economy and Finance of Peru gave a letter to the leader of the group of transport workers.

On 9 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 7 May 2018, merchants started to throw stones, sticks, trash and bottles to police forces after their attempts of moving merchants to a new market in Santa Cruz. Merchants did not want to move and the police forces had to use tear gas to disperse the riots.

On 7 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 6 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 5 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 4 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 3 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 2 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 1 May 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 30 April 2018, protesters in Chuquisaca declared a full strike and blocking of streets in defense of the gas camp Incahuasi. They did not allow any civilian pass the blockades. Civilians of Chuquisaca distrust the government because they believe the central government is biased and that the conflict over the gas camp Incahuasi is a territorial conflict. Chuquisaca residents do not want to lose that camp.

On 27 April 2018, hundreds of people belonging to the Central Obrera Departamental, the Comite Civico and other social organizations and companies, together with students, took to the streets in Sucre (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca), marching around the city and staging a protest at the 25th May Square, to demand the Plurinational Constitutional Court to respect the sentence dictated to freeze the payment of royalties from Incahuasi to Santa Cruz until the conflict is solved. [size=100]

On 26 April 2018, workers from the Sucre Green Areas Municipal Company took to the streets in Sucre city (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca) to demand the dismissal of 2 company executives accused of alleged mismanagement and workplace harassment. [size=no report]

On 26 April 2018, local inhabitants clashed with the police forces in front of the municipal building in San Borja city (San Borja, General Jose Ballivian Segurola, Beni) during a demonstration to demand improvements of the road towards Trinidad and for the local hospital. Police forces used teargas. As a result of the clash, multiple people were injured. Also, buildings surrounding the location of the demonstration were damaged. [size=no report]

On 25 April 2018, in Sucre, Chuquisaca, medicine students, and law students affiliated with URUS clashed with university students affiliated with FUL (at San Francisco Xavier University. Medicine students were demonstrating against the elections for the student centre. Law students were demonstrating against the increase in working hours for the teachers. Medicine and law students arrived at the area and clashed against each other with the use of teargas, firecrackers and rocks. The police forces intervened. As a result, nine students claimed their freedom was restricted, two students were injured, and 10 students were arrested. Also, a journalist from Red Gigavision channel was forced to delete the images from the clash and then was attacked by rioters, who also took his equipment. [size=at least 21]

On 25 April 2018, a group of medicine, law and history university students staged a demonstration against FUL (Local University Federation) at San Francisco Xavier University in Sucre city (Sucre, Oropeza, Chuquisaca) and marched towards the University Coliseum, where the FUL headquarters are. Rioters vandalized the main door of the FUL headquarters. [size=no report]

On 20 April 2018, transportation workers from the First of May Federation clashed with the Free Transportation Association (ATL) at Plaza del Estudiante, La Paz city (La Paz, Pedro Domingo Murillo, La Paz), due to the control of the transportation routes between La Paz and El Alto. Members of the First of May Federation claim that 200 people from ATL participated, and rocks, sticks and sharp implements were used. As a result, 8 people were injured and 2 were arrested. [size=200]

On 19 April 2018, mine workers of Chojlla, held a demonstration in La Paz in front of the Work Ministry offices demanding the authorities to listen to their demands about the managers of the International Mining Company to renounce their positions as they have connections to previous owners who exploited their workers in previous years. [size=no report]

On 18 April 2018, students forcibly took control of the university of San Francisco Xavier building in Sucre, Chuquisaca as a demonstration to demand public announcement of classes at the university. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2018, indigenous people took control of the municipal government offices in Concepcion. The reason was that the mayor needed to comply with promises made to them, and because he did not the indigenous people wanted him to renounce to his position.
On 16 April 2018, protesters of the city of Cobija protested against articles in a law that will increase costs of importations in the no tax zone of the region.

On 11 April 2018, in Huanuni municipality (Oruro), an explosion was reported in a mine, killing 8 workers. The leaders of the worker's union claimed the explosion was not accident, and that it was an attack against the mining workers. Authorship unknown. 9 fatalities.
On 10 April 2018, teachers from Santa Cruz demanded attention of the authorities for the second day in a row in their previous request of more resources, improvement of salaries and fair hours.
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples; Government of Colombia (2010-2018)

On 9 April 2018, in Irupana (La Paz), demonstrators, including farmers, clashed with MAS members and councilmen at the City Hall. The demonstrators have been occupying the building for the previous 8 days, against the current mayor of the city, from the MAS party. It was reported that grenades and dynamite were used in the clash. At least 17 people were reported injured. [size=at least 17]

On 9 April 2018, 50 families of Belen street, in Sucre, Chuquisaca, held a demonstration against the water supply company Elapas, because of the lack of water supply in the sector for over 5 months. [size=50]
On 9 April 2018, teachers from Santa Cruz demanded attention of the authorities in their previous request of more resources, improvement of salaries and fair hours.

On 7 April 2018, municipal workers were injured by merchants when they decommissioned products that were at a sidewalk in Sucre, Chuquisaca. The merchants were unhappy with this and attacked the workers with sticks and other objects. 3 merchants were arrested. [size=no report]

On 5 April 2018, a demonstration was held in La Paz, in front of the Brazilian embassy, to show their discontent with the decision to imprison Lula da Silva in Brazil. They supported the ex president of Brazil and claimed that the judgement against him was fraud. [size=no report]
On 3 April 2018, transport workers protested in Santa Cruz because of the status of highways and demanded maintenance of the streets.

On 2 April 2018, transport workers of FANCESA held a demonstration in Sucre demanding the company to maintain the price of cement bag. The demonstration was part of a strike held for 11 days at the main offices of FANCESA. [size=no report]

On 26 March 2018, farmers held a march as a demonstration to demand the release of 20 farmers that were arrested in the violent confrontations with the police in days before. The march was held in La Paz. [size=no report]

On 22 March 2018, health workers of Chuquisaca staged a demonstration for 48 hours in which they marched towards the SEDES main offices in Sucre, Chuquisaca. The demonstration was held against the initiation of a process against two employees by the authorities of SEDES. Only the first day there was a demonstration, the second day was a peaceful strike [size=no report]

On 22 March 2018, coca leaf farmers tried to take the building of their headquarters in a violent demonstration which was dispersed and controlled by the police forces, who used tear gas to disperse the farmers.

On 21 March 2018, citizens of Sucre blocked a main highway in Sucre, Chuquisaca, that connected to other cities, in a demonstration to demand the Municipality of Sucre to provide a hospital and more motorized assets for police forces. Additionally they demanded a perimeter for schools and more classes. [size=no report]

On 20 March 2018, farmers tried to violently take control of the offices of the Departmental Association of Producers of Coca (Adepcoca) in La Paz, as part of a conflict that has been going on between two farmer groups from Yungas. Police forces intervened and clashed with the group, who decommissioned dynamite and molotov bombs. 17 farmers were arrested [size=no report].

On 19 March 2018, coca leaf producers engaged in fights with the police during their attempts to control the demonstration in La Paz. Police forces used tear and pepper gas to control the farmer's demonstration. 40 people were arrested and 15 police members were injured.

On 17 March 2018, health workers protested with a hunger strike outside the health ministry in La Paz. Their demands are related to the vaccination bonus and supplies for health centers. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Bolivia (2006-2019) Prison Guards

On 14 March 2018, in Santa Cruz de la Sierra (Santa Cruz), prisoners and police forces clashed after the prisoners were trying to take control of the place. The clash resulted in 6 dead prisoners and 1 police officer. The prisoners had taken weapons from the guards, which they used during the clash. 18 prisoners and 6 police members were injured.
On 14 March 2018, workers from Normandia in Santa Cruz de la Sierra protested demanding that municipal authorities to displace informal merchants from the sector.

On 8 March 2018, women rights organizations and women workers staged a demonstration in La Paz for the International Women's Day. The groups demanded equality in pay, and justice of gender-based violence cases. Additionally they demanded protection policies for women. [size=no report]

On 8 March 2018, women rights organizations staged a demonstration in Tarija for the International Women's Day. The groups demanded equality in pay, and justice of gender-based violence cases. Additionally they demanded protection policies for women. [size=no report]
On 7 March 2018, citizens of Yacapani blocked a highway protesting that their public works to be finished and demands to be attended by the mayor of the city.

On 2 March 2018, merchants attacked customs officers that found smuggled merchandize in a truck in Viacha, Ingavi. The attack was done by the labour group in an attempt to recover the merchandize, and injured 4 custom workers and destroyed customs official's cars. [size=30]

On 27 February 2018, transport workers in Ascencion de Guarayos went on strike demanding the fulfillment of the offers made by the government and in support of their companions in Cuatro Canadas. transport workers and passengers clashed. A woman was injured.

On 21 February 2018, the coca producers continued with the strike and demonstration in Yungas, Santa Barbara, La Paz. They demanded roadmaps to sell their products. Later news reported that the strike left 4 people arrested and 2 police officers injured.
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Cochabamba (Cochabamba), many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 Feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re-election protested (MAS movement). [size=many people]
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Trinidad (Beni), many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election protested (MAS movement supporters). [size=many]
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Sucre (Chuquisaca), many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election protested (MAS movement supporters). [size=many people]
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Oruro (Oruro) many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election protested (MAS movement supporters). [size=many people]
On 21 February 2018, many people protested against Evo Morales re-election in Santa Cruz de La Sierra (Santa Cruz). [size=many people]

On 21 February 2018, many people in different cities around Bolivia protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 Feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election turned out.
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Tarija (Tarija), many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election protested (MAS movement supporters). [size=many people]
MAS-IPSP: Movement for Socialism-Political Instrument for the Sovereignty of the Peoples

On 21 February 2018, in Potosi (Potosi), many people protested against the reelection of Evo Morales. They demanded that the election of 21 feb 2016 be respected. Also, people in favor Evo Morales' re election protested (MAS movement supporters). [size=many people]
On 21 February 2018, many people protested against Evo Morales's re-election in La Paz (La Paz). [size=many people]

On 20 February 2018, coca producers continued with their strike and protest. They were against a payment that Adecoca (the coca producers union) has imposed on producers. The Police unblocked the roads and dispersed the protesters with tear gas.
On 19 February 2018, the coca producers union went on strike and protested in Yungas, Santa Barbara, La Paz. They demanded to have roadmaps in order to sell their production.

On 18 February 2018, many protesters gathered in Parque Urbano, Santa Cruz and walked until Cristo Redentor. They demanded that the decision taken in the elections of February 21 be respected. Also, they protested against the continuationof President Evo Morales' tenure.

On 31 January 2018, after the beating a woman received from a Chinese employee from Synohidro, workers started a protest against the company for abuses against them and demanding that the company change their practices and respect employees from the region.

On 30 January 2018, a peaceful protest carried out by workers from Sinohidro to demand higher salaries started. However, a Chinese employee from the company beat a woman that started a labour demand with the company, this outraged the protesters.

On 30 January 2018, citizens from Muyupampa, in Villa Vaca Guzman, protested against the high price and faulty connections of electricity that reaches Muyupampa. Their protest claimed that the government promised cheaper and quality energy, something that has not been given to them.
On 25 January 2018, various streets and highways in La Paz were blocked by transport workers who protested against the acquisition of Pumakatari buses but the Municipality of La Paz.
On 23 January 2018, transport workers blocked the streets for a 2nd day in Cochabamba until they have a direct action and not only an announcement from Evo Morales about eliminating the Penal Code.
On 22 January 2018, transport workers blocked the streets in Cochabamba until they have a direct action and not only an announcement from Evo Morales about eliminating the Penal Code.

On 21 January 2018, a peaceful protest in Santa Cruz wanted to reach the government to respect the people's and worker's rights and to stop the position of the government to reach agreements with the country.
On 19 January 2018, citizens of Tarija protested blocking highways around the city demanding eliminating the new penal code.
On 18 January 2018, transport workers in Santa Cruz protested and claimed that will not accept any kind of agreement unless the penal code is eliminated.
On 16 January 2018, Citizens in Cochabamba protested blocking highways around the city demanding eliminating the penal code.
On 16 January 2018, transport workers in Potosi decided to continue blocking highways in Potosi demanding eliminating the penal code.

On 13 January 2018, Citizens in Santa Cruz protested against Evo Morales running again as president, demanding him to respect the decision the country had taken and to eliminate the penal code. The protest blocked several main streets in Santa Cruz.
On 13 January 2018, In Potosi citizens started their 3rd day protested against the penal code and demanded changes in the code.
On 12 January 2018, In Potosi citizens started their 2nd day protested against the penal code and demanded changes in the code.
On 11 January 2018, Santa Cruz transport workers continued their protest for the government to change the penal code.
On 11 January 2018, after protesters tried to disrupt the Dakar competition in protest against the Penal Code, police members dispersed the protests with tear gas.
On 11 January 2018, In Potosi citizens started their 1st day protested against the penal code and demanded changes in the code.
On 10 January 2018, transport workers and health workers continued their protested by blocking streets in Cochabamba in protest against the penal code demanding abrogation of the code.

On 9 January 2018, transport workers continued for their 2nd day blocking highways in Cochabamba, supporting the health workers strike that wanted to eliminate article 205 and the article 137 that affected their jobs.

On 8 January 2018, in Potosi, vehicles blocked the main highway to Oruro and La Paz to join the protest against the new penal system code and the inclusion of article 205 that dealt about medical malpractice.

On 9 January 2018, transport workers continued for their 2nd day blocking highways in Oruro, supporting the health workers strike that wanted to eliminate article 205 and the article 137 that affected their jobs.
On 8 January 2018, a transport workers blockade was dispersed by police forces in La Paz

On 8 January 2018, in Pando, transport workers joined the protest against the new penal system code and the inclusion of article 205 that dealt about medical malpractice. The police forces dispersed the blockade of trucks in Pando with no confrontation.
On 8 January 2018, in Cochabamba more than 8000 people protested against the new penal system code.

On 8 January 2018, in Santa Cruz, dozens of vehicles blocked the main highway to join the protest against the new penal system code and the inclusion of article 205 that dealt about medical malpractice. The police forces dispersed the blockade of trucks in Pando with no confrontation.

On 8 January 2018, health workers continued on their protest against article 205 about medical malpractice, in Batallas, la Paz. Police forces dispersed the protest with tear gas and detained 4 protesters.

On 8 January 2018, in Oruro health workers protested against the new penal system code and the inclusion of article 205 that dealt about medical malpractice. Police forces dispersed the protest of the blocked highways in that sector.

On 9 January 2018, transport workers continued for their 2nd day blocking highways in Potosi, supporting the health workers strike that wanted to eliminate article 205 and the article 137 that affected their jobs.

On 3 January 2018, in Sucre, Chuquisaca, health workers held a protest in Sucre where president Evo Morales was designating new judicial and constitutional magistrates. The medics on their 42 day of strike wanted to eliminate article 205 that deals with medical malpractice. [size=no report]
